px-3 mt-5 lg:flex lg:px-0"><section id="incArticle" class="post-content w-full space-y-4 lg:w-2/3 font-b text-3"><p>As the news media continues its <a href="https://futurism.com/business-insider-ai-reading-list" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">often-disastrous pivot</a> towards generative artificial intelligence, the most prominent publication yet has jumped on board: the <em>Washington Post</em>, it turns out, has quietly been building an AI tool designed to let underqualified writers publish content in its storied pages.</p><p>According to multiple sources familiar with the plan who <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/03/business/media/washington-post-opinion-ripple.html" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">spoke to the <em>New York Times</em></a>, since April the newspaper has been secretly building a program known as "Ripple" that appears to be part syndication, part talent network akin to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/18/business/media/huffpost-unpaid-contributors.html" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">contributor schemes at <em>HuffPost</em></a> and <a href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/jonchristian/jayson-demers-audienceboom-forbes-entrepreneur-pay-for-play" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue"><em>Forbes</em></a><em>. </em></p><p>The biggest difference from those prior contributor networks and this one, though, is the way the sausage will be made.</p><p>Along with partnerships with established writers, the new program will employ an "AI writing coach" called "Ember" designed to guide "nonprofessionals" through the article-writing process.</p><p>That tool will, per early prototypes described to the <em>NYT</em>, hand-hold aspiring columnists through every aspect of the writing process from start to finish. Its sidebar will instruct writers to devise an "early thesis," list out "supporting points," and provide a "memorable ending" — all while a live AI chatbot weighs in and a "story strength" tracker evaluates their progress.</p><p>At the end of it all, a human editor is said to review the columns before they go to publication — though in practice, similar promises have often ended in disaster, like at <em>CNET</em>, which promised that editors were reviewing the <a href="https://futurism.com/the-byte/cnet-publishing-articles-by-ai" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">scores of AI-generated articles</a> it ran before it turned out they were <a href="https://futurism.com/cnet-ai-errors" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">riddled with errors</a> and <a href="https://futurism.com/cnet-ai-plagiarism" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">plagiarism</a>.</p><p>Though the outputs from <i>WaPo</i>'s program wouldn't be <em>entirely </em>generated by AI, it sounds like everything but. And in practice, as we've seen time and again, the temptation with AI is to use it not as a thoughtful creative partner but as a speedrunning tool to churn out large quantities of low-quality material, or to cook up something that sounds confident but is shaky on the undergirding facts and logic.</p><p>In other words, it sounds like the program could be poised to take everything that's currently broken and controversial about newspaper opinion sections and amplify it using generative AI.</p><p><em>WaPo</em> declined to provide comment for the <em>NYT</em>'s exposé. It's worth noting that the <em>NYT </em>has been putting significant resources of its own into exploring how AI can be responsibly used in journalism — but while it's <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/10/07/reader-center/how-new-york-times-uses-ai-journalism.html" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">using certain machine learning tools</a> for tasks like finding patterns in large datasets, it's pledged not to use generative AI to write any articles.</p><p>The revelation also comes during a period of broader crisis at <em>WaPo</em>, with significant layoffs coming as its owner Jeff Bezos has increasingly exerted control over the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2025/feb/26/jeff-bezos-washington-post-opinion" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">content and ideological leaning</a> of the paper's journalism.</p><p>Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-65609965" href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/03/business/media/washington-post-opinion-ripple.html\"\u003espoke to the \u003cem\u003eNew York Times\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, since April the newspaper biggest difference from those prior contributor networks and this one, though, is the way the sausage will be made.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlong with partnerships with established writers, the new program will employ an \"AI writing coach\" called \"Ember\" designed to guide \"nonprofessionals\" through the article-writing process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat tool will, per early prototypes described to the \u003cem\u003eNYT\u003c/em\u003e, hand-hold aspiring columnists through every aspect of the writing process from start to finish. Its sidebar will instruct writers to devise an \"early thesis,\" list out \"supporting points,\" and provide a \"memorable ending\" — all while a live AI chatbot weighs in and a \"story strength\" tracker evaluates their progress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the end of it all, a human editor is said to review the columns before they go to publication — though in practice, similar promises have often ended in disaster, like at \u003cem\u003eCNET\u003c/em\u003e, which promised that editors were reviewing the \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/the-byte/cnet-publishing-articles-by-ai\"\u003escores of AI-generated articles\u003c/a\u003e it ran before it turned out they were \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/cnet-ai-errors\"\u003eriddled with errors\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/cnet-ai-plagiarism\"\u003eplagiarism\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough the outputs from \u003ci\u003eWaPo\u003c/i\u003e's program wouldn't be \u003cem\u003eentirely \u003c/em\u003egenerated by AI, it sounds like everything but. material, or to cook up something that sounds confident but is shaky on the undergirding facts and logic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn other words, it sounds like the program could be poised to take As the news media continues its often-disastrous pivot towards generative artificial intelligence, the most prominent publication yet has jumped on board: the Washington Post, it turns out, has quietly been building an AI tool designed to let underqualified writers publish content in its storied pages.

According to multiple sources familiar with the plan who spoke to the New York Times, since April the newspaper has been secretly building a program known as "Ripple" that appears to be part syndication, part talent network akin to contributor schemes at HuffPost and Forbes.

The biggest difference from those prior contributor networks and this one, though, is the way the sausage will be made.

Along with partnerships with established writers, the new program will employ an "AI writing coach" called "Ember" designed to guide "nonprofessionals" through the article-writing process.

That tool will, per early prototypes described to the NYT, hand-hold aspiring columnists through every aspect of the writing process from start to finish. Its sidebar will instruct writers to devise an "early thesis," list out "supporting points," and provide a "memorable ending" — all while a live AI chatbot weighs in and a "story strength" tracker evaluates their progress.

At the end of it all, a human editor is said to review the columns before they go to publication — though in practice, similar promises have often ended in disaster, like at CNET, which promised that editors were reviewing the scores of AI-generated articles it ran before it turned out they were riddled with errors and plagiarism.

Though the outputs from WaPo's program wouldn't be entirely generated by AI, it sounds like everything but. And in practice, as we've seen time and again, the temptation with AI is to use it not as a thoughtful creative partner but as a speedrunning tool to churn out large quantities of low-quality material, or to cook up something that sounds confident but is shaky on the undergirding facts and logic.

In other words, it sounds like the program could be poised to take everything that's currently broken and controversial about newspaper opinion sections and amplify it using generative AI.

WaPo declined to provide comment for the NYT's exposé. It's worth noting that the NYT has been putting significant resources of its own into exploring how AI can be responsibly used in journalism — but while it's using certain machine learning tools for tasks like finding patterns in large datasets, it's pledged not to use generative AI to write any articles.

The revelation also comes during a period of broader crisis at WaPo, with significant layoffs coming as its owner Jeff Bezos has increasingly exerted control over the content and ideological leaning of the paper's journalism.

Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, eat your heart out.
